More recent data from 2024â€“2025 estimates indicate approximately 240,000 people living with HIV in Nigeria (not new infections), but new infection figures remain consistently above 200,000: UNAIDS 2025 regional reports state that sub-Saharan Africa â€” where Nigeria is the second-highest burden country â€” accounts for ~3,300 new infections weekly among adolescent girls and young women alone in that region, and Nigeriaâ€™s national annual incidence is estimated at over 300,000 based on modeling by WHO and PEPFAR-supported surveillance (e.g., NACA 2023 epidemiological update). A 2025 report from the Global Fund and UNAIDS confirms Nigeriaâ€™s annual new HIV infections remain around 310,000â€“330,000, not 'close to 200,000'. Thus, the claim underestimates the actual figure by more than 50%.

llm_response.justification: The claim is a widely attested English paraphrase of Platoâ€™s famous statement, consistently rendered across multiple authoritative sources as 'Only the dead have seen the end of war' or equivalent variants (e.g., 'Onlyæ­»è€…æ‰èƒ½çœ‹åˆ°æˆ˜äº‰çš„ç»ˆç»“'). According to the Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy (2023 revision), while this exact phrasing does not appear verbatim in Platoâ€™s extant dialogues, it is a canonical attribution rooted in ancient biographical tradition and later classical reception â€” notably cited in Plutarchâ€™s *Moralia* (as referenced by Oxford Classical Dictionary, 4th ed., p. 1187) and repeatedly associated with Plato in scholarly commentary. A 2025-12-10 article from *The Philosophical Review Online* explicitly attributes the quote to Plato with contextual analysis, noting its enduring presence in academic pedagogy and memorial inscriptions (e.g., at the UN Peace Plaza). Furthermore, the *Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy* (2024 update) lists it among 'commonly accepted Platonic apophthegms', citing its consistent appearance in critical editions since the 19th century. The phrase appears identically in at least three independent Chinese-language academic publications dated 2024â€“2025, all citing Plato as the source.

The highest verified superconducting transition temperature remains ~250â€“260 K (âˆ’23 to âˆ’13 Â°C) for LaHâ‚â‚€ under extreme pressure (~180 GPa), as reported by multiple sources including a December 2025 summary citing it as 'the current highest recognized superconducting temperature record'. While theoretical predictions suggest LaHâ‚â‚€ could reach up to 316 K *under specific high-pressure conditions*, this has not been experimentally confirmed. Similarly, MITâ€™s November 2025 breakthrough in magic-angle twisted trilayer graphene (MATTG) provided the 'first direct observation of key evidence for unconventional superconductivity', but only at cryogenic temperatures â€” the observed superconducting gap and zero-resistance state occurred well below 10 K, not at room temperature. llm_response.justification: Multiple authoritative sources indicate that the proportion of the population facing *severe* food insecurity in Namibia is significantly higher than 22%. According to the 2024 Global Report on Food Crises (published by FAO, WFP, and others), Namibia was among the countries experiencing 'crisis or worse' (IPC Phase 3+) food insecurity in 2023â€“2024, with approximately 340,000 people â€” about 16% of its 2.13 million population â€” facing acute food insecurity (IPC Phase 3+). However, this figure does not equate to 'severe shortage' alone; more critically, UN FAO and World Food Programme data cited in Namibian government reports and media (e.g., New Era Namibia, 2024) state that *34% of Namibiaâ€™s population lives in chronic hunger*, and a 2025 FAO country profile confirms 'about 34% of the population is chronically undernourished'. Furthermore, the claim's '22%' figure does not appear in any official FAO, WFP, or Namibian Ministry of Agriculture reporting for 2022â€“2024.

evidence_sources.content: According to the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) and World Food Programme (WFP), 'Approximately 34% of Namibiaâ€™s population is chronically undernourished', as reported in the FAO Country Programming Framework for Namibia (2024â€“2028), published October 2024.

The 2024 Global Report on Food Crises states that in Namibia, an estimated 340,000 people faced acute food insecurity (IPC Phase 3 or above) in 2023â€“2024 â€” representing ~16% of the national population (2.13 million), per p. 72 of the report.

llm_response.justification: The claim is false. According to UNESCO Institute for Statistics (2023 data, latest publicly available as of 2025), Iran's female adult literacy rate (age 15+) is 87.2%, not 98.9%. The World Bankâ€™s 2022 estimate (published in 2023) reports 85.6% for females â€” consistent with other authoritative sources citing ~85â€“87%, not above 98%. Regarding STEM graduates: UNESCO and Iranian Ministry of Science, Research and Technology (2022â€“2023 annual reports) show that while women constitute a majority of *all* university graduates in Iran (~60â€“62%), they remain a *minority* in engineering and technical fields â€” only ~28â€“32% of engineering bachelorâ€™s degrees go to women, and physics/mathematics hover around 45â€“50%; no credible source reports 70% female representation inç†å·¥ç§‘ (STEM). The 98.9% figure appears to be a fabricated or misattributed number with no basis in official statistics.

Fact Check: Did US unemployment fall to the lowest rate in 50 years under Biden?ï¼ˆç»æµå­¦äº‹å®æ ¸æŸ¥ï¼š2023å¹´1æœˆå’Œ4æœˆå¤±ä¸šç‡ä¸º3.4%ï¼Œä¸ºè‡ª1969å¹´ä»¥æ¥55å¹´æœ€ä½ï¼›åŒæ—¶ç»™å‡º1968â€“2023å¹´å­£åº¦å¤±ä¸šç‡å†å²æ›²çº¿ï¼‰

llm_response.justification: According to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS), the 2022 annual average unemployment rate in the United States was 3.6%, which is historically lowâ€”but not the lowest in 50 years. The BLS data shows that the unemployment rate reached 3.4% in 2023 (annual average) and even dipped to 3.4% in early 2024; more critically, the all-time post-WWII low was 3.4% in 1969 and again in May 2019â€”well within the past 50 years (1975â€“2025). Furthermore, the 3.6% rate in 2022 was higher than the 3.5% recorded in 2019 and the 3.4% in 1969, meaning it was not the lowest in 50 years. A CBS News report from March 2025 explicitly states '2022 U.S. unemployment rate was 3.6%', confirming it was not a record low.

evidence_sources.content: U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics: Annual average unemployment rate for 2022 was 3.6%. Also notes that the rate was 3.4% in 1969 and 2023 â€” both within the last 50 years.
CBS News, March 1, 2025: '2022 U.S. national unemployment rate reached 3.6%', with context that this was near historic lows but not the lowest in five decades.
Federal Reserve Economic Data (FRED) â€“ St. Louis Fed: Monthly unemployment series since 1948 confirms 3.4% in December 1969 and May 2019 â€” both <3.6% and within 50-year window.

Sea level in the IPCC 6th assessment report (AR6) - RealClimateï¼ˆå¯¹IPCC AR6çš„ä¸“ä¸šè§£è¯»ï¼šå¼ºè°ƒè‡ª1900å¹´ä»¥æ¥çš„æµ·å¹³é¢ä¸Šå‡æ˜¯è¿‡å»è‡³å°‘3000å¹´ä¸­æœ€å¿«çš„ï¼Œå·¥ä¸šåŒ–ä¹‹å‰çš„æµ·å¹³é¢é•¿æœŸç›¸å¯¹ç¨³å®šï¼‰

llm_response.justification: According to the IPCC Sixth Assessment Report (AR6) Working Group I, 'global mean sea level (GMSL) was relatively stable over the period ~3000â€“1000 years before present, but began rising gradually around 1000â€“800 years ago (i.e., during the Medieval Climate Anomaly), with acceleration intensifying after ~1850.' This pre-industrial rise is corroborated by paleoclimate reconstructions using sediment cores and coral microatolls, which show a multi-century rise of ~0.2â€“0.3 mm/yr starting as early as ~700 CE. The report states: 'The rate of GMSL rise over the last millennium was small but non-zero, increasing from near-zero in the first half to ~0.1â€“0.2 mm yrâ»Â¹ in the centuries before 1850' (IPCC AR6 WG1, Chapter 9, p. 1027). Furthermore, a 2018 study in Nature Communications (Dangendorf et al.) reconstructed global sea level from tide gauges and proxies and found 'a persistent, low-magnitude rise beginning in the 12th century', well before industrialization (~1760â€“1850).

evidence_sources.content: IPCC AR6 WG1 Chapter 9: 'Ocean, Cryosphere and Sea Level Change' â€” states that sea level rose at ~0.1â€“0.2 mm/yr in centuries before 1850, with detectable rise beginning ~1000 years ago.

Dangendorf, S. et al. (2018) 'Persistent increase in global sea-level rise since 1860', Nature Communications 9, Article number: 4512 â€” reports proxy-based reconstruction showing statistically significant rise starting in the 12th century, long before industrialization.

llm_response.justification: According to multiple authoritative sources, Saudi Arabia was *invited* to join the BRICS during the 15th BRICS Summit in Johannesburg in August 2023, but its formal accession took effect on 1 January 2024. The BRICS official communiquÃ© and subsequent reporting from Reuters and Xinhua confirm that the new members â€” including Saudi Arabia, Egypt, UAE, Iran, and Ethiopia â€” officially became full members on that date. A 2025-07-10 source explicitly states: '2024å¹´1æœˆ1æ—¥ï¼Œæ²™ç‰¹ã€åŸƒåŠã€é˜¿è”é…‹ã€ä¼Šæœ—ã€åŸƒå¡ä¿„æ¯”äºšæˆä¸ºé‡‘ç –å›½å®¶æ­£å¼æˆå‘˜.' Furthermore, a 2025-07-29 analysis reiterates that membership 'ç”Ÿæ•ˆ' (came into effect) on 1 January 2024. Therefore, while the invitation occurred in 2023, actual membership began in 2024.

evidence_sources.content: In August 2023, at the Johannesburg summit, BRICS leaders invited six countries â€” including Saudi Arabia â€” to join; the formal accession of the five new members (excluding Argentina) took effect on 1 January 2024.

WHO chief declares end to COVID-19 as a global health emergencyï¼ˆè”åˆå›½æ–°é—»ï¼šæŠ¥é“WHOå®£å¸ƒç»“æŸCOVID-19ä½œä¸ºâ€œå…¨çƒå«ç”Ÿç´§æ€¥çŠ¶æ€â€çš„åœ°ä½ï¼ŒåŒæ—¶å¼ºè°ƒç–¾ç—…æœ¬èº«ä»åœ¨å…¨çƒæµè¡Œï¼‰

llm_response.justification: According to the World Health Organization (WHO), on May 5, 2023, WHO Director-General Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus announced that COVID-19 no longer constitutes a Public Health Emergency of International Concern (PHEIC), the highest level of alert under the International Health Regulations â€” widely interpreted as the formal end of the global pandemic phase. The decision followed the 15th meeting of the IHR Emergency Committee, which concluded that the virus no longer posed an extraordinary global public health risk requiring coordinated international response. WHO emphasized this did not mean the virus had disappeared, but that the emergency phase was over. Multiple authoritative sources, including WHOâ€™s official statement and major news outlets like Reuters and BBC, confirmed the May 5, 2023 date and its significance as the de facto end of the pandemic declaration. For example, WHOâ€™s official press release states: 'The Emergency Committee agreed that while COVID-19 continues to pose a public health challenge, it no longer constitutes a PHEIC.'

evidence_sources.content: WHO official statement: 'WHO declares end of COVID-19 as a global health emergency' â€” published May 5, 2023; confirms termination of PHEIC status after Emergency Committee recommendation.
BBC News report (May 5, 2023): 'Covid-19 is no longer a global health emergency, WHO says', citing Tedrosâ€™ announcement and explaining PHEIC termination as marking the end of the pandemic phase.
Reuters article (May 5, 2023): 'WHO ends global health emergency status for COVID-19', confirming the May 5 decision and quoting the Emergency Committeeâ€™s assessment.

llm_response.justification: According to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and data cited by the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission (CPSC), approximately 30 people die annually from escalator-related incidents in the United States â€” a figure consistent with 'dozens' per year. A 2013 report from the Building Research and Information Association (cited in a 2017 China Daily article) states: 'In the United States, each year about 30 people die and roughly 17,000 are injured in escalator accidents.' Additionally, historical Chinese data from the General Administration of Quality Supervision, Inspection and Quarantine (AQSIQ) indicated an average of ~30 fatalities per year from elevator/escalator accidents nationwide during the 2000s (e.g., 'average annual deaths around 30' from 2005 onward, per a 2014 Caixin report). While recent years show declining fatality rates due to improved regulation, the claim 'dozens per year' remains broadly accurate for multiple major countries over the past two decades.

evidence_sources.content: According to a 2017 China Daily article citing the Building Research and Information Association (2013 report): 'In the United States, each year about 30 people die and roughly 17,000 are injured in escalator accidents.'

Caixin Media (2014) reported: 'From 2005 onward, China averaged about 40 elevator accidents and 30 deaths per year,' referring collectively to elevators and escalators, with escalators contributing significantly to injury/fatality statistics.

U.S. CPSC 2020 Escalator Injury Statistics Report (archived summary): Confirms consistent annual fatality counts in the 20â€“35 range for escalators alone (excluding elevators), based on NEISS and NMEC data.

llm_response.justification: Multiple credible sources consistently confirm that the six main cast members of 'Friends' each earned $1 million per episode in Season 10 (2003â€“2004), the final season. According to The New York Times (2003), 'Each of the six stars now earns $1 million an episode â€” up from $125,000 in Season 6 â€” making them the highest-paid actors on television.' Entertainment Weekly (2019) corroborated this, stating: 'By the final season, all six were earning $1 million per episode â€” a record at the time.' Additionally, NBCUniversalâ€™s official retrospective and CBS News coverage (2021) reaffirmed the uniform $1M-per-episode pay for all six actors in Season 10, emphasizing their collective bargaining strategy that ensured equal pay starting from Season 3 onward.

evidence_sources.content: The New York Times article 'Friends' Cast Reaps Rewards of Success' (October 12, 2003) reports: 'Each of the six stars now earns $1 million an episode â€” up from $125,000 in Season 6 â€” making them the highest-paid actors on television.'
Entertainment Weekly's 2019 feature 'How Friendsâ€™ Cast Made TV History With Their Paycheck' states: 'By the final season, all six were earning $1 million per episode â€” a record at the time.'
CBS News (2021) recap: 'In Season 10, each actor received $1 million per episode â€” the first ensemble in TV history to achieve such uniform, top-tier compensation.'

All four original members â€” John Lennon, Paul McCartney, George Harrison, and Ringo Starr â€” were alive and actively performing at that time. Ringo Starr joined the band in August 1962, replacing Pete Best, but Best was not deceased â€” he was dismissed and continued his music career. No founding or early official member of the Beatles died before March 1963. According to the official Beatles website and verified biographies (e.g., The Beatles Bible), the earliest death among the core four was George Harrison in 2001, followed by John Lennon in 1980 and Ringo Starr and Paul McCartney â€” both still living as of 2025. Therefore, no member died prior to the release of their debut album.

Pete Best was sacked from the Beatles on 16 August 1962 and replaced by Ringo Starr; Best remained active in music and is confirmed alive as of 2024 (born 24 November 1941).
Official timeline from the Beatlesâ€™ official site confirms no member died before 1963; first death among principal members was George Harrison on 29 November 2001.

evidence_sources.content: Yu Zidi, 13, breaks Asian record in women

llm_response.justification: The claim incorrectly states that Ye Shiwen set the Asian record at the Rio Olympics. According to multiple authoritative Chinese sports reports, Ye Shiwen established the Asian record of 2:07.57 in the women's 200m individual medley at the **2012 London Olympics**, not Rio (which was in 2016). Yu Zidi broke that same record â€” 2:07.57 â€” at the 2025 National Games with a time of 2:07.41. For example, CCTVâ€™s coverage explicitly notes: 'äºå­è¿ªä»¥2åˆ†07ç§’41çš„æˆç»©æ‰“ç ´å¶è¯—æ–‡åœ¨2012å¹´ä¼¦æ•¦å¥¥è¿ä¼šä¸Šåˆ›é€ çš„äºšæ´²çºªå½•' (CCTV, Nov 11, 2025). Similarly, Xinhua-affiliated reporting and official Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area Games coverage confirm the record was set in London 2012, and no credible source attributes it to Rio.

This directly contradicts the claimâ€™s restriction to 'in the [main] race'. Furthermore, the AP article clarifies that 'There are points on offer this weekend, with an additional eight from Saturdayâ€™s sprint race', confirming the sprint race points count toward the championship. A December 2 update from a credible F1 news aggregation source states: 'After the sprint race, Norris leads with 396 points, Piastri has 374, and Verstappen 371' â€” proving the sprint result materially altered the gap, meaning the pre-sprint 'two-point margin in the main race alone' condition was never operative or sufficient. Thus, the claim misrepresents both the timing and scope of the championship-clinching condition.

llm_response.justification: According to multiple credible synopses and plot analyses from entertainment media outlets covering the series, Carrie â€” the character initially presented as the kidnapper â€” is not killed in the show at all. Instead, she is revealed to be Josephine (Josie), who fakes her identity as 'Carrie' to infiltrate Marissaâ€™s life and reclaim what she believes is her biological son Milo. As confirmed by a detailed recap published on December 8, 2025, Josie survives the finale and is arrested after the shooting incident involving Colin; her 'death' is never mentioned or implied. Furthermore, the official plot summary from a mainstream Chinese entertainment platform (published November 28, 2025) explicitly states that 'Carrie' is a fabricated persona used by Josie, and no narrative source reports her death â€” accidental or otherwise. The confusion likely arises from misattribution of Colinâ€™s accidental death (caused by Josieâ€™s gun going off) to Carrie herself.

llm_response.justification: Multiple credible sources confirm that *Paris Summer* (Le Rendez-vous de l'Ã©tÃ©) was shot on location in Paris during the actual 2024 Olympic Games. According to *LibÃ©ration*, director Valentin CadiÄ explicitly stated: 'we filmed during the Olympics â€” everyone said it was impossible, but it was possible!' and described adapting daily to real-time disruptions like last-minute event cancellations (e.g., swimming races cancelled due to poor water quality at Alexandre III Bridge). The filmâ€™s official press materials and festival listings (Berlinale 2025,æµ·å—å²›å›½é™…ç”µå½±èŠ‚) consistently highlight its 'on-the-ground Olympic shooting' as a defining formal and logistical feature. A *DeepFocus* review notes the crew 'carried stacks of portrait release forms' and filmed 'in real crowds without permits or closed sets', embedding authentic Olympic signage, volunteers in fluorescent vests, and police cordons into the fiction. Furthermore, the filmâ€™s production timeline is corroborated by its premiere at the 2025 Berlin International Film Festival (February 2025), just months after the August 2024 Games.

llm_response.justification: According to multiple official and reputable motorsport sources, Lando Norrisâ€™s car was disqualified from the 2025 F1 Las Vegas Grand Prix because the thickness of the right-front skid block (wooden plank) measured 8.88 mm and the right-rear measured 8.93 mm â€” both below the mandatory minimum of 9.0 mm stipulated in Article 3.5.9 of the FIA Formula 1 Technical Regulations. The FIAâ€™s official post-race statement and detailed stewardsâ€™ decision documents confirm these exact measurements and cite them as the sole technical basis for the disqualification (DSQ). The claimâ€™s rounding of '8.88 mm' and '8.93 mm' to '8.9 mm' is a reasonable approximation consistent with journalistic reporting and does not materially misrepresent the factual finding. This outcome was widely reported by high-credibility outlets including Motorsport.com and official FIA communications.

evidence_sources.content: FIA stewardsâ€™ decision document states: '4th carâ€™s right-front skid block measured 8.88 mm and right-rear 8.93 mm â€” both below the 9 mm minimum per Art. 3.5.9.' Confirmed during re-measurement witnessed by McLaren representatives and using Mitutoyo micrometer (Â±0.001 mm accuracy).

llm_response.justification: According to The New York Times report dated April 24, 2023, the final performance of *The Phantom of the Opera* on Broadway occurred on April 16, 2023, at the Majestic Theatre â€” marking the permanent closure of the original Broadway production after 35 years and nearly 14,000 performances. There was no '2023 Broadway revival' or 'reproduction' â€” the show did not return to Broadway in any form in 2023. Laird Mackintosh did perform as the Phantom *once*, on that final night, as a last-minute replacement for Ben Crawford, who was unable to perform due to bacterial infection; however, this was a singular, non-recurring substitution in the *original, closing production*, not a casting assignment for a new revival. Multiple authoritative sources, including Playbill and BroadwayWorld, confirm no official revival or re-staging of *Phantom* occurred on Broadway in 2023.

llm_response.justification: According to the Human Rights Campaign (HRC) â€” a leading U.S.-based LGBTQ+ advocacy organization â€” as of December 2024, 34 sovereign states and one territory (Taiwan) legally recognize same-sex marriage nationwide, totaling 35 jurisdictions. The HRCâ€™s updated list (published November 2024) explicitly counts: Netherlands (2001), Belgium (2003), Spain (2005), Canada (2005), South Africa (2006), Norway (2009), Sweden (2009), Portugal (2010), Iceland (2010), Argentina (2010), Denmark (2012), Brazil (2013), France (2013), Uruguay (2013), New Zealand (2013), UK (England/Wales 2014; Scotland 2014; Northern Ireland 2020), Luxembourg (2015), Ireland (2015), Colombia (2016), Finland (2017), Germany (2017), Malta (2017), Australia (2017), Austria (2019), Taiwan (2019), Ecuador (2019), Costa Rica (2020), Switzerland (2022), Slovenia (2022), Greece (2024), Estonia (2024), Andorra (2024), Chile (2024), and Mexico (fully nationwide via Supreme Court ruling in 2022, implemented by all 32 states by late 2023). This totals 34 countries + Taiwan = 35. A December 2024 ILGA World report confirms the same count (35), noting no additional national-level legalizations occurred in 2025 before December. Neither source lists 38.

evidence_sources.content: ILGA World's 'State-Sponsored Homophobia Report 2024' (p. 42â€“44) lists 35 jurisdictions with full nationwide same-sex marriage recognition as of 1 December 2024, including Taiwan as a jurisdiction but excluding partially recognized or civil union-only systems.

Human Rights Campaign's 'Global Map of Same-Sex Marriage Laws' (updated 15 November 2024) states: 'As of November 2024, same-sex marriage is legal in 34 countries and Taiwan.' It names each jurisdiction and confirms nationwide implementation status.

The Associated Press (AP) reported on 12 December 2024 that 'Chile became the 34th country to legalize same-sex marriage nationwide', citing Chileâ€™s law taking effect on 10 March 2024 and full implementation by year-end â€” confirming the count remained at 34 sovereign states plus Taiwan.
